Kuhn Conceptualization Resources Writing – review & editing Visualization Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Department of Chemical, Biological, and Materials Engineering, University of South Florida, United States Department of Chemical, Biological, and Materials Engineering, University of South Florida United States Department of Chemical, Biological, and Materials Engineering, University of South Florida b National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, United States National Renewable Energy Laboratory Golden CO United States National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, Colorado, United States ⁎ Corresponding authors. Dry reforming catalysts, especially those with activity at moderate temperatures, have been intensely investigated to enhance the conversion of biogas. Here, Ru is evaluated as a promoter for Ni-Mg based catalysts. Catalysts based on 1.4 wt%Ni-1.0 wt%Mg-Ce0.6Zr0.4O2 with Ru (0.02–0.32 wt%) were prepared using incipient wetness. The reducibility of the catalysts and conversions increased with increasing Ru content. Increases in conversions with increasing Ru loading was attributed to the additional active sites and synergistic effect between Ru and Ni, which weakened Ni-Mg interactions. Samples showed dry reforming activity at low temperatures (450–510 °C). Reaction rates and activation energies of higher loading Ru samples (1.4 wt%Ni-1.0 wt%Mg/Ce0.6Zr0.4 O2 with 0.16 and 0.32 wt%Ru) decreased when the reduction temperature was raised from 300 to 400 °C. A 20 h TOS study showed stable catalytic activity with minimal coke deposition. The results suggest that Ru is an alternative to Pt in promoting low temperature dry reforming of methane. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Low temperature dry reforming Biogas conversion Metal loading Reduction temperature Ru-Ni-Mg-ceria zirconia catalysts Data Availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction A proposed route to make renewable liquid fuels and chemicals is reforming of biogas (consisting primarily of methane and CO2) to make syngas followed by Fisher-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS). Due to the distributed nature of the raw materials used to produce biogas, these processes are anticipated to be at small scale in the future, which makes the economics very challenging. A potential way to lower the cost is to seek integration between reforming and syngas conversion reactions, which could be achieved by high-performing catalysts that minimize the common pressure and temperature differences. With CO2 already a substantial component of biogas, dry reforming (RXN1) is a candidate reaction for conversion of methane also contained in it. Inclusion of dry reforming avoids costly CO2 separations and also improves the overall carbon efficiency of the process. However, a limitation of dry reforming is that it yields a H2: CO ratio of 1 whereas typical hydrocarbon-based fuels and chemicals have approximately -CH2- backbones. A second limitation is that the reverse water gas shift (RXN2) occurs simultaneously, yielding H2:CO ratios of less than 1. Although this limitation can be minimized by operating conditions (e.g., high temperatures, >800 °C), such a solution would prevent improved integration with the syngas conversion steps. A third limitation of dry reforming of stability, mainly coke formation. Steam reforming (RXN3) is an analogue of dry reforming with than advantages of steam being a better oxidant and higher H2 production. In industrial steam reforming, steam is fed in excess to methane to aid in limitation of coking by thermodynamic and kinetic arguments [1]. However, the same idea with CO2 is less feasible since increasing its concentration in the feed will accelerate the RWGS (RXN2) and, from a practical standpoint, biogas sites would have limited purified CO2 available. Bi-reforming (RXN4) [2–4] is a reaction that overcomes the limitations of dry reforming while still permitting substantial CO2 conversions. The addition of steam to biogas for bi-reforming improves selectivity to H2:CO ratios ∼ 2 by adding more hydrogen atoms to the feed and improves stability since steam is a better oxidant than CO2. Since steam is a product of the RWGS, it also limits this reaction via product addition. Since it is the more challenging reaction, the focus is on dry reforming as a model reaction for catalytic biogas upgrading in this study. With the selectivity able to be tuned by feed ratios, the catalyst performance priorities are activity and stability. (RXN1) Dry reforming CH 4 + CO 2 → 2 H 2 + 2 CO ( Δ H ° = 247.3 kJ / mol ) (RXN2) RWGS CO 2 + H 2 → CO + H 2 O ( Δ H ° = − 41 kJ / mol ) (RXN3) Steam reforming CH 4 + H 2 O → 3 H 2 + CO ( Δ H ° = 206.3 kJ / mol ) (RXN4) Bi-reforming 3 C H 4 + C O 2 + 2 H 2 O → 4 CO + 8 H 2 ( Δ H ° = 219.6 kJ / mol CH 4 ) Dry reforming of methane to produce syngas has attracted much attention in the literature [5–10]; however, there is still much interest in developing low-cost and efficient catalytic materials capable of driving the reforming technology at low temperatures (below 600 °C). Metals such as nickel and cobalt supported on materials such as alumina, ceria, and zirconia are some of the common choice catalyst systems due to their cost and availability, but they are mostly highly active at high-temperature conditions and have a high tendency to deactivate via coking. Several studies have shown that observed improvement in their catalytic performance (reducibility, activity, and stability) can be obtained with the promotion of Ni-based metals with platinum group metals such as platinum, ruthenium, or rhodium [11,12]. Although platinum group materials are costly, using them in small amounts in catalyst formulation could turn out to be advantageous when factors such as the energy requirements and cost of catalyst regeneration or replacement are considered. In our previous works [13,14], we showed that promoting a Ni-Mg/ceria-zirconia (Ni-Mg/CZO) based sample with small loadings of Pt (0.16 wt%) resulted in higher conversion and reaction rates due a balance of improved reducibility and basicity. A review of reported price trends of the precious metals [15,16] and literature based on noble-metal promoted reforming catalyst materials suggested Ru as a possible replacement for Pt. Several literature studies have evaluated Ru as reforming catalysts. Chen et al. [17] studied the relationship between the catalytic performance and structure on Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 supported Ru catalysts. Liu et al. [18] presented results from a methane dry reforming study conducted at temperatures between 400 and 700 °C using 0.5 wt% Ru supported on different oxide materials (CeO2, Al2O3, and TiO2). Whang et al. [19] studied the support effect on the domain size of 0.13 wt% Ru metal particles. They found that the Ru particle size decreased from 6.3 to 1.4 nm upon changing the support from SiO2 to ZrO2-SiO2. The Ru/ZrO2-SiO2 was also active and stable at 800 °C with no coke formation. In addition to active metal(s) and support material selection for reforming, the sample reduction conditions also influence the catalyst performance[20]. The reduction temperature used can also affect the catalyst stability/ coke formation [21], the phase of the support material [22], metal particle morphology, and size [23]. Chen et al. [24] et al. studied the effect of reduction temperature on CO formation rate from the dry reforming reaction using Ni0.03Mg0.97O and noble-metal (Pt, Pd, Rh) promoted Ni0.03Mg0.97O samples. They reported that increasing the reduction temperature from 650 to 850 °C increased the catalytic activity of the Ni0.03Mg0.97O and the increase may be due to the difficulty in reducing the Ni2+ in Ni0.03Mg0.97O at a lower temperature. However, the reduction temperature caused no change in the catalytic activity of the bimetallic samples due to already existing enhanced reducibility in samples because of noble metal presence. Similarly, Osaki[25] studied the effect of reduction temperature on the performance of Ni/TiO2 CO2 reforming catalyst. Reductions performed at 400 and 300 °C caused changes in the rate constant of the reaction, CO adsorption amount, and methane dissociation. The effect of reducing a Ni/MgO catalyst at 550 °C and 800 °C was studied by Usman and Daud [21]. Their results showed that reducing the sample at higher temperatures caused catalyst deactivation. This study focuses on the performance of Ru-Ni-Mg/ceria-zirconia catalysts for dry reforming at low-temperature conditions (primarily 450–510 °C). Dry reforming is considered a model reaction for biogas upgrading via catalysis. Catalyst activity and stability are prioritized over selectivity. For promising catalysts and conditions, bi-reforming (RXN 4)[2] can be employed to achieve desired H2:CO ratios. For a series of catalyst with various Ru loadings, detailed characterization and reaction testing studies were performed, which indicated interplay between Ru, Ni, and Mg in these catalyst systems. Both composition and reduction temperature are demonstrated as design parameters to achieve high performing and stable catalyst in this temperature range. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reagents/chemicals and catalyst preparation The mixed oxide ceria-zirconia support was prepared using the co-precipitation method. Cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (REacton; 99.5 %; Alfa Aesar), zirconium dinitrate oxide hydrate (99.9 %; Alfa Aesar), and ammonium hydroxide were used during synthesis. The supported-metal samples were prepared using the incipient wetness method and the following metal precursors: ruthenium nitrosyl nitrate (Ru 31.3 % min; Alfa Aesar), nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (puratronic 99.9985 %; Alfa Aesar), and magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (ACS, 98.0–101.0 %; Alfa Aesar). More detailed information on the catalyst preparation has been documented in our previous works [13,26]. All gases in this study were purchased from Airgas and obtained at 99.999 % ultra-high purity. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts 2.2.1 Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) Powder X-ray diffraction analysis was conducted with a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer containing an X-ray generator with a Cu tube with Kα radiation: 0.15418 nm. The scan was performed between 2θ angles of 10–90° using a PSD fast scan mode at 0.4 time/step(s). The diffraction patterns were evaluated and matched using X’Pert Highscore Plus software. 2.2.2 Nitrogen physisorption analysis (N2-physisorption) The N2-physisorption analysis was performed with ∼100 mg of catalyst samples using a Quantachrome Autosorb-IQ gas sorption analyzer. The samples were outgassed for 5.4 h at a final outgas temperature of 200 °C before being placed in the analysis station. The specific surface areas of the samples were calculated by fitting data obtained between the P/Po range of 0.05–0.33 with the BET method. The pore volumes, average pore sizes, and pore size distribution were obtained using the BJH method. 2.2.3 Transmission Electron Microscopy TEM samples were prepared by drop-casting onto a thin C support film TEM grid. TEM images were obtained on a FEI Tecnai G230 SuperTwin TEM operated at 300 kV. 2.2.4 Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The reducibility of the catalyst samples was characterized using a U-tube reactor and mass spectrometer system. The samples (75 mg) were pretreated under 50 SCCM of He (ultra-high purity) at 150 °C for 30 min and then cooled down to 50 °C before introducing a gas mixture containing 5 % H2/He (50 SCCM total). The furnace temperature was then increased from 50 to 900 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min after several min of stable gas flow. 2.2.5 DRIFTS study FTIR experiments were conducted Nicolet IS50 spectrometer from Thermo Scientific. DRIFTS experiments were conducted with catalysts loaded in a high pressure/high temperature-resistant reactor cell from Harrick Scientific with two ZnSe windows and one quartz window. A flow system to feed gases was used, and similar to that used for the measuring catalyst performance. Further details can be found in an earlier study [2]. For the CO DRIFTS study, the sample was placed on KBr powder in a reactor cell and pretreated at 200 °C for 30 min under Ar (30 SCCM). The pretreated sample was later reduced at 400 °C (0.16Ru/CZO at 300 °C) for an hr. The sample surface was purged with only Ar at the reduction temperature to remove residual H2 gas and cooled to room temperature. The background and no CO spectra were then obtained before the adsorption of CO (ultrahigh purity) at room temperature. The spectra were collected at select time intervals after Ar purge using a resolution of 2 and data spacing of 0.241 cm-1 (150 scans total). CO2 adsorption DRIFTS study at 400 °C, was conducted using a DRIFTS-MS experiment set up. The experiment was conducted using approx. 55 mg of the sample that was reduced in situ before a gas mixture consisting of CO2/Ar = 1.75/23.25 SCCM was flowed over it. The CO2/Ar mixture was flowed for 1 hr and spectra were taken at 10 min intervals. The sample spectra were also taken at 5 min intervals for the entire 30 min of sample surface purge with only Ar flow. A switching experiment involving two cycles of 20 min flow of CH4 and CO2 was conducted using approx. 55 mg of catalyst sample using 1.75 SCCM CH4/CO2 diluted with Ar (23.25 SCCM). After sample reduction, the following gas flow cycle was used: CO2/Ar gas mixture was first flowed for 20 min, followed by 20 min flow of CH4/Ar gas mixture, another cycle of CO2/Ar gas mixture flow was carried out and finally, the second cycle of CH4/Ar gas mixture was done to complete the switching experiment. Methane reforming was also studied using an in-situ DRIFTS experiment to observe what surface species were present during the reaction. The experiment was carried out at three temperature conditions (300, 350, and 400 °C) for 30 min of steady-state using a CH4/CO2/He= 1.75/1.75/21.5 SCCM gas mixture. 2.2.6 Raman spectroscopy Laser Raman spectroscopy was conducted on powdered fresh and spent samples at room temperature using a Horiba Jobin-Yvon LabRam HR800 spectrometer with a 50x long working distance (LWD) objective microprobe in the backscattering geometry and a 532 nm Nd:YAG frequency-doubled laser (Torus). 2.2.7 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The X-ray photoelectron measurements were done using a ULVAC-PHI XPS machine equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV). The correction of the peaks obtained at the different element regions was done using the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV as the reference. Spectra of the following regions: C 1s, O 1s, Ce 3d, Zr 3d, Ni 2p, Mg 1s, and Ru 3d were obtained, and the raw data was fitted using XPS peak processing software. Linear and Tougaard background types were used as appropriate for background subtractions. 2.2.8 CO Chemisorption CO chemisorption was performed on an Altamira AMI-300 Lite instrument utilizing a TCD (135 mA, gain setting of 10). All flow rates were 25 SCCM. Catalyst samples (ca. 100 mg) were heated from 50 °C at 5 K/min to 300 °C in 4 %H2/Ar and held for 1 h then purged and cooled in helium to 30 °C. Pulsed CO adsorption (25 pulses) was done using a 500 uL sample loop of 10 % CO/He into a helium stream. Uptake was calculated using pulses 21–25 as the saturation value. 2.3 Catalysts performance tests Temperature-programmed and steady-state dry reforming experiments were conducted to evaluate the catalyst performance. The temperature-programmed experiment was performed using approximately 75 mg of samples, and 20 mg of samples were used for steady-state experiments to ensure the conversions were below the thermodynamic limits. The experiments' gas feed consisted of CH4, CO2, and He (3.08 SCCM, 3.08 SCCM, and 37.84 SCCM), respectively. The samples were activated using a 5 % H2/He gas mixture before both the temperature-programmed and dry-reforming experiments. The sample reduction for the initial steady-state experiments was carried out at 300 °C and the reaction results obtained thereafter have been denoted with R300 at the end of catalyst names. The temperature-programmed reaction was carried out by linearly increasing the temperature from 200 to 900 °C using a ramp rate of 10 °C/min. The steady-state experiment was conducted at four different temperature conditions (450, 470, 490, and 510 °C). Both the temperature-programmed and steady-state experiments were conducted at atmospheric pressure. The experiments set up for the performance tests consisted of a flow U-tube reactor (ID = 4 mm), a Thermolyne furnace with a Eurotherm 2116 PID controller, and the effluent gas analysis was done using an online MKS cirrus 2 mass spectrometer (Faraday detector). The reactant conversions, H2/CO, and reaction rates (R) were calculated using Eqs. (1)–(3), respectively. XCH4 (%) and XCO2 (%) are CH4 and CO2 conversions, F(in) and F(out) are the molar flowrates at the reactor inlet and outlet for the respective reactant gas and GHSV is the gas hourly space velocity: (1) X CH 4 % = F CH 4 in − F CH 4 out F CH 4 in * 100 (2) X CO 2 % = F CO 2 in − F CO 2 out F CO 2 in * 100 (3) H 2 / CO = F H 2 F CO (4) R µmol g cat . s = GHSV µmol g cat . s * conversion X * reactant concentration (5) Turnover frequency TOF / s − 1 = R CH 4 D CH 4 Also, the turnover frequency (TOF) based on the CH4 consumption rate was calculated using Eq. (5), where DCH4 is the density of the surface-active sites for CO adsorption obtained from pulse CO chemisorption experiments. For steady-state experiments, carbon balances were closed within + /- 4 %. The uncertainty in the H2:CO ratio increases with decreasing reactant conversions. 3 Results 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 Material porosity The BJH pore size distribution of the fresh samples obtained using N2-physisorption analysis is shown in Fig. S1A. The samples had a narrow unimodal pore size distribution with a larger fraction of the pores being below 10 nm, resulting in average pore size values of 8.4–9.8 nm (Table S1). The ceria-zirconia support had the broadest pore size distribution. The supported metal samples are average-sized mesoporous materials with specific surface areas ranging from 21.8 to 30.7 m2/g (Table S1), and this is a reduction in the specific surface area of the ceria-zirconia support of 45 m2/g [13]. The filling of the pores of the ceria-zirconia support of pore volume of 0.10 cm3/g with various amounts of Ru, Ni, and Mg metals decreased the pore volume to 0.06 cm3/g, and there was no significant effect in pore volume for the various supported Ru samples (Table S1). 3.1.2 Sample crystallinity/phase identification The Raman spectra of the 0.16Ru/CZO and the other samples with higher loadings of Ru (0.08 wt%, 0.16 wt%, and 0.32 wt%) are shown in Fig. S1B. Only the Raman spectra of these down-selected samples were presented because we observed that metal impregnation (1.4 wt% Ni, 1.0 wt% Mg, and 0.02–0.32 wt% Ru) did not cause any noticeable change in various spectra obtained. One major vibration band at around 470 cm-1 and two weak broad bands at around 304 and 618 cm-1 was seen in the ceria-zirconia support (Fig. S1B). The sharp intense band at around 470 cm-1, which is due to F2g vibration bands of fluorite-structured ceria[27] and the other two defect-induced D broad bands (308 and 681 cm-1) remained present after metal impregnation as seen in the spectra of the supported metals shown in Fig. S1B. The information on sample crystallinity and phase obtained from Raman spectroscopy is corroborated with the X-ray diffraction patterns obtained and shown in Fig. S1C. The major features present with corresponding lattice parameters at 28.9° (111), 33.5° (200), 47.9° (220), and 56.9° (311) are representative of the cubic-fluorite structure of ceria [28]. The absence of characteristic diffraction patterns for NiO, MgO, RuO2, or metal alloys can be due to high metal dispersion[29], low metal loadings [30], and/or small particle size [29] which is below the detection limit. In addition, this can be an indication that NiO, MgO, and RuO species and their alloys possibly have a crystallite size of < 5 nm [31]. 3.1.3 TEM measurements To obtain information on the morphology and interatomic spacing, TEM micrographs and HRTEM images of the 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO were also obtained ( Fig. 1). The identified d spacing and the corresponding elements they belong to include: 0.34 (ceria [32]), 0.32, 0.30 (ceria)[33], 0.29, 0.28, 0.27 (ceria [33]), 0.25 (NiO (111) [34] / MgO [35]), 0.20 (Ni0 (111) [31,34] / MgO [35]), 0.16 (ceria [33]) nm. The EDS profile fresh 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO (Fig. S2) indicated minimal Ru signal, which was just above the noise level, despite being the highest loading considered in this study. This finding is similar to what was observed in the PXRD and Raman analysis results obtained. Other elements such as Ce, Zr, O, Ni, and Mg present in were detected. 3.1.4 Catalyst reducibility H2-TPR studies were used to investigate the interaction of the various metal with the ceria-zirconia support. The reduction profiles presented are divided into two different regions, low and high temperature (HT), highlighted in Fig. 2. The reduction of the support material has been reported in previous literature [26], with peaks due to the surface ceria (400–600 °C) and the bulk ceria (> 600 °C). The reduction peak observed in the HT region (664 and 800 °C) in all samples is due to the reduction of bulk ceria [36]. Considering the HT reduction is similar in all samples, only the low temperature (< 600 °C) would be discussed. The addition of NiO and MgO into the support caused a decrease in the reduction temperature to 385 °C, which is below the previously reported NiO reduction temperature of 405 °C. The reduction of surface ceria in the 1.4 wt%Ni-1.0 wt%Mg/CZO (NiMg/CZO) occurred at a lower temperature of 258 °C with an additional reduction owing to NiO occurring at 385 °C (Fig. 2A). In the presence of only Ru (0.16Ru/CZO), the reduction of surface ceria occurred at a much lower temperature of 95 °C, presenting a sharp peak which contrasts with the broad peak presented by just CZO support. The peak sharpness indicates the occurrence of an additional reduction of RuO2 species in close interaction with surface ceria species [37,38]. The low-temperature reduction is due to the presence of noble metals promoting the spillover of H2 species onto the ceria surface [39]. The reduction profile of 0.16Ru-Ni/CZO presented two peaks at 168 and 371 °C. The addition of Mg to the 0.16Ru-Ni/CZO sample resulted in the reducibility of NiO i.e., judging from the height and width of the reduction at 348 °C. The reduction profiles of the Ru-1.4Ni-1.0Mg-CZO samples with varying amounts of Ru (0.02–0.32 wt%) are shown in Fig. 2B. The reduction profiles of samples containing 0.02 and 0.04 wt% Ru looked like that of the samples containing no Ru (NiMg/CZO), with a shoulder for the reduction of surface ceria. However, the addition of 0.02 and 0.04 wt%Ru shifted the reduction of surface ceria and NiO to lower temperatures. Increasing the Ru content to 0.08 wt%Ru led to a difference in the reduction profiles of the Ru-NiMg/CZO samples with a distinct peak for surface ceria and a broad peak for the reduction of NiO. It can be concluded that the presence of Ru enhanced the reducibility of ceria and NiO, however, this enhancement is more observable in the samples containing Ru with the loading of 0.08 wt% and beyond. The reduction of NiO at lower temperatures in the presence of Ru shows that the metal-support interaction between NiO and CZO was weakened by the interaction between Ru and Ni. 3.1.5 XPS measurements Spectra of several element regions of select samples (0.16Ru/CZO, 0.16Ru-Ni/CZO, and 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO samples) obtained from XPS measurements are shown in Fig. S3. Two peaks belonging to O-CO and C-C were observed in the C 1s spectra of 0.16Ru/CZO. The addition of NiO led to the presence of an additional peak belonging to O-C-O at 287.1 eV. The 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO sample had similar peaks to the 0.16Ru/CZO sample but with the O-CO peak at a lower energy of 289.5 eV. Ce 3d5/2 peaks and satellite peaks belonging to Ce4+ were present in the Ce 3d region spectra of all three samples (Fig. S3B). The lower Ce 3d5/2 peak area of 0.16Ru/CZO is due to increased metal-support interaction of the sample in comparison to the others and the presence of additional metals impregnated into the support material. The peak at 181.6 ( ± 0.7) eV in the Zr 3d region of the three samples belongs to ZrO2. In a similar fashion to the Ce 3d region, the Zr 3d peak area of 0.16Ru/CZO was also the lowest. Also, the presence of NiO in 0.16Ru-Ni/CZO led to the presence of an additional peak belonging to ZrOH (182.6 eV). The O 1s spectra of the samples were deconvoluted into three different peak regions belonging to Oα lattice oxygen species (O2-), Oβ oxygen vacancies (surface) O-, and O2 -/ OH- [40]. As compared in Table S2, the addition of NiO (0.16Ru-Ni/CZO) led to a reduction in the concentration of lattice oxygen species and while the addition of MgO increased the concentration of lattice oxygen species. Of the three samples, 0.16Ru-Ni/CZO had the lowest amount of lattice oxygen species while 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO had the highest concentration of lattice oxygen species. The number of O- species increased upon the addition of NiO and a further increase was observed with the addition of MgO, causing the 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO to have the highest amount of O- species. The lattice oxygen species present in these samples contribute to the dry reforming reaction by reacting with O2- to form carbonates (CO3 2-) [41]. The OH- species react with CO2 resulting in the formation of hydrogen carbonates (HCO3 -)[41]. The Ni 2p region XPS scan of the two samples surveyed (0.16Ru-Ni/CZO and 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO) presented two peaks belonging to Ni 2p3/2 (Ni 2+) and its satellite peak [42]. The peak near 856 is due to Ni2O3 [31]. The higher surface concentration of Ni 2p3/2 upon the inclusion of Mg in the 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO is an indication that shows a reduction in the interaction between Ni and Ru with the addition of Mg. A single peak belonging to Mg2+ was present at 1304.4 eV in the Mg 1s region of the 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO sample (Fig. S3G). Peak belonging to Ruº at a binding energy of 280.4 eV was observed only in the 0.16Ru/CZO sample. The absence of this peak in the 0.16Ru-Ni/CZO and 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO samples can either be caused by interaction between Ru and Ni in the 0.16Ru-Ni/MgO as observed in the metal reducibility studies or due to the reduction in the surface concentration of Ru on the catalyst via addition of other metals near the surface. 3.1.6 CO DRIFTS study and CO chemisorption The spectra ( Fig. 3A, see Tables 1 and 2 for peak identification) indicated carbonyl peaks present at 1979, 2000, and 2055 cm-1 in the 0.16Ru/CZO sample and only a lower intensity peak for the strongly bound CO present at 2055 cm-1 was observed in the 0.16Ru-Ni/CZO. The bands tend to be broad, which suggests (based on literature [43,44]) several types of adsorbate-surface pairs are likely present. A range of vibrational energies results as the local environments are different. Detailed moieties have been proposed [43] and range from bridged (CO-Ru2) to tricarbonyl species at the respective low and high ends of frequencies observed here. The addition of Mg led to the disappearance of the carbonyl peaks at 1979, 2000, and 2055 cm-1, and this is due to the further reduction in the exposed Ru metallic sites upon additional metal impregnation. Another hypothesis is the blocking of the Ru adsorption sites by carbon species. The presence of carbonate peaks likely formed via CO reacting with adsorbed oxygen-containing species (e.g., hydroxyls or molecular oxygen), though CO disproportionation reaction has not eliminated as a possibility. The sample with 0.08Ru-NiMg/CZO had the lowest peak intensity in comparison to the samples with higher Ru loading (Fig. 3B) indicating carbonate formation is dependent on Ru loading. To further support the CO DRIFTS results, pulse CO chemisorption was performed, and the results are shown in Table 3 with R300 and R400 indicating the pulse chemisorption experiment was conducted after sample reduction at 300 and 400 °C. For R300 samples, the catalyst support (CZO) had the lowest CO uptake (0.9 µmol/gcat) in comparison to the supported metal catalyst, this shows that after catalyst activation at 300 °C, CZO has little or no capacity for CO adsorption. The addition of 1.4 wt% Ni and 1.0 wt% Mg increased the CO uptake to 4.2 µmol/gcat owing to the presence of some Ni species for CO adsorption. The 0.16Ru/CZO sample had a 24 times increase in CO uptake in comparison to CZO alone and the addition of 1.4 wt%Ni led to an additional 1.3 times increase in CO uptake (28.4 µmol/gcat) proving that Ni provides additional CO adsorption sites. The addition of 1.0 wt% Mg led to a significant decrease in the CO uptake from 4.2 to 1.7 µmol/gcat and this shift is correlated to decreased reducibility of surface Ni species due to its interaction with Mg, likely in the form of a (Ni,Mg)O mixed oxide. The result agrees with this result from CO DRIFTS (Fig. 3A), in which no band belonging to the CO adsorption site was found, and TPR (Fig. 2A), which showed shifts to higher reduction temperatures when Mg was added to Ni-Ru/CZO. TPR is declared to be an outstanding technique for determination of the mixed oxide phase [45]. Unfortunately, the loadings are too low to observe the phase via XRD, but has been at high loadings relative [26] to this study. Thus, this explanation of MgO interactions with Ni to lower reducibility seems valid. 3.2 Catalyst performance test (Temperature-programmed reaction) As an initial screening, temperature-programmed reactions ( Fig. 4) evaluated the effect of changes in reaction temperature on conversions and H2/CO molar ratio. The ceria-zirconia support showed no activity at low-temperature conditions with 10 % CH4 and CO2 conversions obtained at 828 and 787 °C, respectively. The 10 % reactants’ conversion temperatures were reduced with the addition of Ni and Mg (1.4Ni-1.0Mg/CZO (no Ru present)) reduced to 807 °C for CH4 and 769 °C for CO2, respectively. The addition of 0.02 wt% Ru to the 1.4Ni-1.0Mg/CZO sample caused small changes in the 10 % conversion temperatures with the temperature difference in conversion temperatures between 1.4Ni-1.0Mg/CZO and 0.02Ru-NiMg/CZO being less than 5 °C. The decrease in conversion temperatures with increasing Ru loading was consistent with a further increase in Ru loading to 0.08, 0.16, and 0.32 wt% Ru. The impact on conversion temperature changes with change in Ru amount became less significant after 0.08 wt% Ru, and there were minimal changes in the conversion temperatures reported for both the 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO and 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO samples. Additionally, the CO2 conversions were higher than the methane conversion indicating the occurrence of the reverse water gas shift reaction, an expected side reaction during dry reforming. Relatedly, H2/CO values (Table S3) were less than 1, ∼0.41–0.45 at T = 450 °C. Due to the inactivity of samples with ≤ 0.04 wt% Ru at 450 °C, no H2:CO value was reported. 3.3 Catalyst performance test (Steady-state reaction) Following the samples' performances in temperature-programmed reaction, down-selected samples (0.08Ru-NiMg/CZO, 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO, and 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO) were tested in steady-state experiments at temperatures between 450 and 510 °C and at an increased WHSV of ∼131,300 cm3/h/g (4x higher than in Section 3.2). To verify this down-selection, several additional tests with the low Ru loading samples were conducted. At 450 °C and WHSV of ∼35,200 cm3/h/g, samples with lower Ru loading (lower than 0.08 wt% Ru) showed no reforming activity. The results obtained (Fig. S4) between 470 and 510 °C and a lower WHSV of 8800 cm3/h/g showed that the CH4 and CO2 conversions at 510 °C, which initially was at ∼6 and ∼ 9 % respectively, decreased in less than 30 min and could be caused by restructuring of the active components at these temperatures. Also, no CH4 conversion was measured at 490 and 470 °C, which further indicates the poor catalytic activity of 0.04Ru-NiMg/CZO. The CH4 and CO2 conversions from the samples with higher Ru loading (0.08–0.32 wt%) are presented in Fig. 5 and Tables S4 and S5. Both CH4 and CO2 conversion increased with an increase in temperature (450–510 °C) over the individual catalyst samples as expected owing to the endothermic nature of dry reforming. Consistent with Fig. 4, there is a rapid increase in conversion for catalysts in the intermediate range (0.02–0.08 wt% Ru), with limited further increases at higher loadings (0.16 wt% and above). This trend is consistent with high dispersion at low loadings and subsequent decreases with increasing loading. Unfortunately, quantitative measurement of dispersion for bimetallic samples is difficult by CO chemisorption. However, TOFs for methane conversion based CO chemisorption quantified sites yields a similar trend. As noted in Table 3, CO uptake generally increased, although in a non-linear manner, with Ru loading. Such complexity indicated substantial changes in how the Ru decorates the other components of the catalyst. At the highest loading (0.32 wt% Ru), the Ru loading has reached a critical value behaves more like 0.16Ru/CZO. This difference, in contrast to catalysts with lower Ru loadings, is evident in the TOFs ( Fig. 6). The 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO catalyst has more sites, but less active ones, as compared to the catalysts with lower Ru loadings. Given that there is a maximum in the TOF, at the sample with 0.16 wt% Ru, the trend infers an optimal morphology, perhaps as simple as Ru cluster size, decorating the more prevalent components of the catalyst. A key parameter could also be distance to reducible species. As noted in Fig. 2B, there is a substantial behavior change for reduction only when increasing from 0.04 to 0.08 wt% Ru. Beyond activity comparison, selectivity is also a critical discussion point since all H2:CO ratios are less than 1 (Fig. S5), the ideal stoichiometric amount for dry reforming. As noted earlier, the occurrence of reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction, a thermodynamically favored reaction over dry reforming with decreasing temperature, is a factor. The activation energies for CO2 conversion are lower than that of CH4 (Table S6). As a result, the conversion rates become closer together with increasing temperature and, thus, the H2:CO ratios increase with temperature. In addition to the temperature trends, the H2:CO ratios were generally higher as the Ru loading increased. Considering that Ru is likely a better catalyst than Ni for the RWGS (i.e., Ni is likely considered a poor catalyst at these conditions), this finding suggests increased methane conversion induced by Ru is the reason for the increased H2:CO with increasing Ru loading. As a final point, H2:CO ratios of less than 1 also indicate the lack of coke formation. In cases of severe coking, the methane is able to decompose and still form gas-phase H2. However, CO2 is unable to rapidly enough oxidize the carbon deposits and, thus, little CO is formed, which results in a H2:CO ratio > 1. 3.4 In-situ DRIFTS study with 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO The results obtained from the in-situ CO2 adsorption study conducted at 400 °C are shown in Fig. 7. After the initial flow of CO2 gas over the catalyst surface, three vibration bands were observed at 2360, 1549, and 1352 cm-1. The band at 2360 cm-1 belongs to CO2 gas[54], the band at 1549 cm-1 which shifted to a lower wavenumber of 1536 cm-1 after 60 min of CO2 flow can be attributed to monodentate carbonate [55] and the last band at 1352 cm-1 was due to the formation of bidentate carbonate species [48]. These results indicate that the surface reaction during CO2 adsorption involves the direct adsorption of CO2 and its subsequent reaction with hydroxyl groups [56]. The absence of vibration bands due to carbonyls suggests that the dissociative adsorption of CO2 was not a facile reaction on the 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO. A weak peak at ∼ 2000 cm-1 provides slight evidence of surface CO formation via disproportionation. Based on literature [57,58], this band is assigned to CO linearly adsorbed on metallic Ni/Ru at low to moderate coverages. No gas-phase CO was observed, which indicated minimal, if any, CO desorption. To evaluate how the presence of a second reactant (CH4) would influence the surface reaction, a CH4-CO2 switching experiment was also conducted at the same temperature condition of 400 °C and the results are presented in Fig. 8 and Fig. S6. In a similar fashion to the CO2 adsorption DRIFTS study, monodentate carbonate (1539 cm-1), monodentate carbonate/formate (1342 cm-1), hydrogen carbonate (1045 cm-1) was present after the first CO2 flow and the intensity of these bands increased with increasing time of CO2 flow. After the cease of the first flow cycle of CO2 (g) and the subsequent introduction of the initial CH4 gas flow, the CO2 gas band decreased in intensity with increasing time of CH4 (g) flow. At 10 min of CH4 flow, in addition to the presence of a band belonging to CH4, bands belonging to CO gas and adsorbed CO species (2105, 1951, and 1868 cm-1) were also observed in the obtained IR spectra. As mentioned earlier, this range of adsorbed species indicates various types of surface sites and coverages identified in literature. The presence of CO gas and adsorbed CO is probably due the reaction between surface atomic carbon and lattice oxygen species following a series of reaction to decompose adsorbed methane to atomic carbon and hydrogen [59]. The IR spectra obtained from the CH4 reforming experiment conducted at steady-state temperature conditions (350, 400, and 450 °C) are shown in Fig. 9. The bands for gas-phaseCO2 and CH4 were respectively observed at 2359 cm-1 [54] and at 3017 cm-1 [54]. Bidentate carbonate, which was present at 1584, 1578, and 1566 cm-1 at 350, 400, and 450 °C, respectively, [48,59] and bands belonging to formate species were observed at 1338 cm-1 [54]. The band at 2010 cm-1 can be ascribed to linearly adsorbed CO species metallic Ru and/or Ni metallic sites, isolated Ru sites surrounded by slightly positive Ru atoms, or highly faceted Ru surfaces [44,57,58]. Due to the high Ni loadings relative to Ru, dominance by Ni in contributing to the band intensities could be envisioned. It is noteworthy to mention that no such band was observed in spectra obtained from the CO adsorption study (Fig. 3B). 3.5 Time on stream (TOS) study and post-reaction characterization The following down-selected catalysts (0.08Ru-NiMg/CZO, 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO, and 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO) which were tested in steady-state experiments (450–510 °C) were further exposed to dry reforming conditions at 450 C for 20 h. Following the 20 h TOS experiment, the samples were characterized using Raman spectroscopy analysis, and the results are shown in Fig. S7. The absence of both G bands for graphitic carbon and D bands indicates that very negligible or no carbon was deposited on the samples. To further confirm the catalyst stability, an additional 20 h run of dry reforming experiment was conducted with 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO, and both the CH4 and CO2 conversions were relatively stable for the entire duration of the experiment ( Fig. 10). The temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) profile of the sample shown in Fig. S8 confirms that only a negligible amount of carbon was deposited during the experiment ( Table 4). Some of the peak areas were below 200 °C, a temperature condition that does not favor the oxidation of deposited carbon. It is more likely that the CO2 peak below 200 °C is due to physisorbed CO2. The coke formation rate of 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO did not change at a higher reduction temperature of 400 °C (Table 4), indicating that changing the reduction temperature from 300 to 400 °C did not affect the rate of carbon deposition. Also, the amount of coke deposited on 0.32Ru-1.4Ni-CZO is significantly lower than those reported by other studies (Table 4). 4 Discussion 4.1 Roles of Ni, Ru, and changes in Ru loading Ru addition helps to lower the reduction of the surface ceria, a much lower reduction temperature of ∼100 °C (Fig. 2) was recorded with 0.16Ru/CZO as against a reported 618 °C [13] for the support alone. Also, the presence of Ru in the Ru-NiMg/CZO sample reduces the interaction between Ni and Mg as seen when comparing the reduction temperature of NiO in NiMg/CZO and Ru-NiMg/CZO (Fig. 2). NiO in 1.4Ni-1.0Mg/CZO reduced at 385 °C while upon addition of Ru, the reduction temperature of NiO shifted to a lower temperature. The lower temperature condition indicates that the Ru reduces the interaction between NiO and MgO in the NiO-MgO solid solution and aids the reducibility of NiO species. Ru addition also enhances the catalytic activity, a reduction in X10CH4 temperature from 807 °C over NiMg/CZO to 803 °C with 0.02Ru-NiMg/CZO and even further to 442 °C in 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO was observed (Table S3). These results obtained from the catalyst reducibility and catalyst performance study indicate that Ru is acting as both an active metal for the dry reforming reaction, and a promoter of the reducibility of NiO and ceria. NiO provides additional active metal sites for the dry reforming reaction as shown from the 10 % and 50 % reactant conversion temperature shown in Table S3. Lower reactant conversion temperatures were recorded over 0.16Ru-Ni/CZO in comparison to 0.16Ru-CZO. Also, the CO uptake amount (Table 3), increased from 21.8 µmol/gcat (0.16Ru/CZO) to 28.4 µmol/gcat (0.16Ru-Ni/CZO) with the addition of Ni. MgO was chosen as an addition promoter because of results from our previous work which showed that MgO addition suppresses coke formation[14]. It was also observed that the addition of Mg in the following catalyst formulation (0.08Ru-NiMg/CZO, 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO, and 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO) lead to a reduction in metal dispersion as reported in the CO DRIFTS and CO chemisorption above. However, this low metal dispersion did not translate to poor catalytic activity, indicating that the catalyst activity is not only a function of the surface metal atoms. 4.2 Effect of changes in reduction temperature The difference in CO uptake amount obtained after catalyst reduction at 300 °C and reduction at 400 °C is shown in Table 3. That of 0.08Ru-NiMg/CZO was minimal, so we cannot categorically imply that the observed difference resulted from changing the catalyst activation temperature. However, that of 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO decreased with changing the reduction temperature from 300 °C (8 µmol/gcat) to 400 °C (6.8 µmol/gcat). Fig. 5 compares the reaction rates obtained from samples reduced at 300 °C (denoted as R300) and those reduced at 400 °C (denoted as R400) before the reforming experiment. The CH4 rate (R300) and CO2 rate (R300) of 0.08Ru-NiMg/CZO were lower than that obtained following catalyst activation at 400 °C. The increase in reaction rate was attributed to an additional reduction of NiO at a higher reduction temperature of 400 °C which led to an increased in the availability of active Ni metal species for CH4 activation. At the lower reduction temperature (300 °C), the complete reduction of NiO has not occurred, and this is supported by the reduction profile shown in Fig. 2B which shows that the reduction of NiO still occurs after 300 °C. Conversely, as shown in Fig. 5B and C. CH4 rate (R300) and CO2 rate (R300) of both 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO and 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO samples were higher than the reaction rates gotten after catalyst reduction at 400 °C. The decrease in reaction rate can be attributed to a reduction of active metal sites due to metal sintering at a higher reduction of 400 °C [21]. The lower CO uptake obtained with 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO after reduction at 400 °C (Table 3) further proves the possibility of lower active metal sites because of particle sintering occurring. The calculated apparent CH4 and CO2 activation energy values were also influenced by changing the sample reduction temperature (Table S6). The activation energies for 0.08Ru-NiMg/CZO were reduced by increasing the sample’s reduction temperature from 300 to 400 °C while those of 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO and 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO samples increased with increasing the reduction temperature from 300 to 400 °C. For both reaction rates (R300) and reaction rates (R400), the CO2 activation energies were lower than the CH4 activation energies due to both the dry reforming and reverse water gas shift reaction pathways exiting for CO2 [13]. Changing the reduction temperature condition of the 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO before 20 h time on stream dry reforming experiment did not lead to any noticeable change in the carbon deposition rate (Fig. S8) and similar coking rates were gotten from the spent 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO-R300 and 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO-R400 (Table 4). This similarity in the coke formation rate is an indication that the decrease in reaction rate that occurred from increasing the reduction temperature condition of the 0.32Ru-NiMg/CZO sample is more likely because of metal sintering and not a difference in coke formation amount. 4.3 Comparison of Ru-Ni-Mg-CZO to Pt-Ni-Mg-CZO CH4 and CO2 conversions of Pt-based samples (0.16Pt-1.34Ni-1.0Mg-CZO and 0.16Pt-2.7Ni-0.50Mg-CZO) and that of Ru based sample with similar loading of 0.16 wt (0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO) from this current study are compared in Fig. S9 and Table S7. At the lower temperature conditions (400–500 °C), the Ru-based samples (0.16Ru/CZO & 0.16Ru-NiMg/CZO) have higher conversions than the Pt-based samples (0.16Pt-CZO & 0.16Pt-1.34Ni-1.0Mg/Ce0.6Zr0.4O2). In addition to catalyst performance, Ru metals are less costly than Pt as indicated by the current price trends [62]. The atomic weight of Ru is substantial lower than that of Pt so increased active sites (at least at similar conversions) could also contribute the enhanced performance of the Ru-based catalysts. The apparent activation energy for 0.16Ru-1.4Ni-1.0Mg-CZO was low in comparison to those obtained from our previous studies using similar loadings of Pt [13,14] showing the possibility of developing a cost-effective catalyst with comparable or improved activity while not sacrificing selectivity. 5 Conclusion From the work carried out in this study, reducibility and metal chemisorption ability were identified to be a function of metal loading and the interactions between metals and the metal-support interaction. Two active metals in the catalyst combination (Ru and Ni) greatly influenced the reducibility of the support material and the reforming activity of the samples (methane activation). The reducibility of both the surface ceria and NiO in the NiO-MgO solid solutions of Ru-Ni-Mg-CZO samples increased with increasing Ru loadings. Temperature-programmed reduction experiments indicated that the addition of Ru weakened the Ni-Mg interaction thereby lowering the reduction temperature of NiO. The Ru loading also lowered the reduction temperature of surface ceria most likely due to hydrogen spillover. Temperature-programmed reduction and steady state reaction studies indicated the strong influence of Ru as a promoter. CH4 and CO2 conversions increased with increasing Ru loadings. Steady-state experiments conducted with select Ru-Ni-Mg-CZO samples (0.08–0.32 wt%Ru) showed dry reforming activity between 450 and 510 °C, similar to the results reported earlier with Pt as the promoter. The samples studied in this paper are not active at low-temperature conditions at Ru loadings below 0.08 wt% Ru. Changing the reduction temperature from 300 to 400 °C increased the activity of the catalyst with lower Ru loading (0.08 wt% Ru) while the opposite effect was observed in the samples with higher loadings (0.16 and 0.32 wt%Ru). This is most likely due to an increase in available active metal sites in the case of 0.08Ru-NiMg/CZO sample and particle agglomeration at higher Ru loadings. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming catalysts, especially those with activity at moderate temperatures, have been intensely investigated to enhance the conversion of biogas. Here, Ru is evaluated as a promoter for Ni-Mg based catalysts. Catalysts based on 1.4 wt%Ni-1.0 wt%Mg-Ce0.6Zr0.4O2 with Ru (0.02–0.32 wt%) were prepared using incipient wetness. The reducibility of the catalysts and conversions increased with increasing Ru content. Increases in conversions with increasing Ru loading was attributed to the additional active sites and synergistic effect between Ru and Ni, which weakened Ni-Mg interactions. Samples showed dry reforming activity at low temperatures (450–510 °C). Reaction rates and activation energies of higher loading Ru samples (1.4 wt%Ni-1.0 wt%Mg/Ce0.6Zr0.4 O2 with 0.16 and 0.32 wt%Ru) decreased when the reduction temperature was raised from 300 to 400 °C. A 20 h TOS study showed stable catalytic activity with minimal coke deposition. The results suggest that Ru is an alternative to Pt in promoting low temperature dry reforming of methane.
coredata.dc:title: Low temperature dry reforming of methane using Ru-Ni-Mg/ceria-zirconia catalysts: Effect of Ru loading and reduction temperature
